Matrices and Transformations (Ch. 3)

$T : \mathbb{R}^m \to \mathbb{R}^n$
$T$ is a linear transformation if $\forall u,v,c$:
- $T(u + v) = T(u) + T(v)$
- $T(cu) = c T(u)$

Primary example:
$T(x) = Ax$
$A$ is an $n \times m$ matrix means $T : \mathbb{R}^m \to \mathbb{R}^n$

$range(T)$ is the possible values we can attain in $\mathbb{R}^n$; that is, the possible values of $Ax, x \in \mathbb{R}^m$; that is, the possible values for $b$ in $Ax = b$.
$range(T)$ is $\{ T(u) : u \in \mathbb{R}^m \} = \{ Au : u \in \mathbb{R}^m \}$
If $A = \matrixstart a_1 \dots a_m \matrixend$, then $range(A) = span(a_1, \dots, a_m)$

$T$ is onto:
Geometrically, all values are possible
$\forall w \in \mathbb{R}^n (\exists u : T(u) = w)$
$Ax = b$ is always solvable
(Every row has a leading $1$)
(No row of $0$s at the bottom)

$T$ is one-to-one:
$\forall w \in \mathbb{R}^n \left[(\exists! u : T(u) = w) \lor (\forall u : T(u) \neq w)\right]$
$Ax = b$ has $1$ or $0$ solutions
(No free variables)
(Means that $a_1, \dots, a_m$ are linearly independent)

$T(e_k) = a_k$ for $T(x) = Ax, e_i = \matrixstart 0 \\ \vdots \\ 1_i \\ \vdots \\ 0 \matrixend$
i.e., $A = \matrixstart T(e_1) & \dots & T(e_m) \matrixend$

Rotation by angle $\alpha$
Linear Transformation!
$T(u)$ is $u$ rotated counter-clockwise by $\alpha$
$T(u) = Au = \matrixstart \cos(\alpha) & -\sin(\alpha) \\ \sin(\alpha) & \cos(\alpha) \matrixend$
